awd_titl_txt: Sensor aided millimeter wave communication for connected vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
Automotive and aerial vehicles are being equipped with more sensors to enhance automated driving/flying as well as to perform general sensing tasks. Despite increasing data rates from cameras, LIDAR, and RADAR, along with higher levels of onboard computation, such vehicles do not have the means to share such high rate sensor data to enhance their situational awareness or improve cooperation. Millimeter-wave communication is one solution for high data rate vehicular communications. Achieving the highest rates with millimeter-wave, though, requires frequent link reconfiguration in mobile environments. This research is aimed at using the information derived from sensors that operate in some band other than the communication band, to help configure the communication link. The emphasis is placed on theoretical development and experimental validation of frameworks of using sensor information to permit link reconfiguration in mobile environments. Broader impacts include teaching, mentoring, participation of underrepresented groups, community outreach through demos and videos, and technology transfer through collaborations with industry partners. 

This research project addresses the fundamentals of communication using side information derived from various sensing techniques. The project leverages mathematical tools from array signal processing and machine learning and will focus on the applications related to beam configuration. On the theoretical side, this project develops mathematical tools for understanding the frequency of beam realignment, a framework for relating radar and communication paths, and fundamental limits for sensor-aided beam alignment in millimeter-wave communication. On the practical side, this project tests critical hypothesis about statistical correlations between sensor measurements and communication link performance in a series of testbeds. The testbeds support low-cost radar derived from WiFi signals and higher cost automotive radars, coupled with custom developed millimeter-wave communication link capability. Outcomes of this research include (i) an understanding of how much overhead can be reduced by using information derived from potentially very different communication bands, and (ii) rapidly reconfigurable and robust millimeter-wave communication links.

por.por_cntn:
The number of sensors on automotive and aerial vehicles, and the data generated by these sensors is increasing. In the case of autonomous ground vehicles, the data needs to be shared for safety, automation, and infotainment applications. In the case of aerial vehicles, this data needs to be transported to a ground station for further processing. Due to the large available bandwidth at millimeter wave (mmWave) frequencies, mmWave systems can support this data exchange. The high bandwidth at mmWave, however, comes with challenges in terms of cost, power and hardware constraints. Due to these constraints, configuring the antenna arrays, which are a critical component of mmWave systems, is challenging. This project developed new approaches for configuring mmWave communication links.

The research focused on several interconnected themes related to mmWave link configuration, as detailed below. We developed several methods for improving communication with large antenna arrays. To mitigate misfocus effects in near-field beamforming, we developed a new spatial coding technique. To improve data rates using dense antenna arrays, we developed analyses of communication link performance that include radiated power, intrinsic noise and extrinsic noise to explain how data rates scale with antenna density. We devised new methods for integrating radar and communications. We created a new design for an adaptive waveform that makes it possible to implement tradeoffs between communications and radar. To demonstrate the practicality of joint communication and radar, we developed a joint communication and radar testbed that shows how good performance can be achieved even with low resolution data converters as long as good algorithms are designed. In our work, we considered applications of mmWave link configuration to aerial vehicles, performing analysis of the likelihood that the strong line-of-sight link is blocked. We also examined at applications of mmWave to vehicular beamforming problems, for example, devising methods to reduce the time to establish and track the mmWave communication channel. Our work, though, applies to mmWave communication links more broadly.

In terms of broader impacts, the research solves important problems related to supporting the high data rates required by vehicles in next generation cellular systems. This opens the potential of new kinds of vehicular automation that can take advantage of high data rate information exchange.

Results from the project were disseminated widely through publications in conferences, journals, and overview articles, with early access to such publications facilitated through preprint servers. Technology transfer was facilitated by incorporating material from the project into high visibility invited talks at conferences and companies, as well as in presentations to affiliate companies as well as internships by the graduate students working on the project.
